awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Higher Brauer Groups and Topological Azumaya Algebras
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is focused on algebraic geometry and algebraic topology, two areas of modern mathematics. Algebraic geometry has ancient origins with many connections to real-world problems. Its goal is to understand the geometry of solutions sets of polynomial equations, equations of central importance in various disciplines, such as theoretical physics, cryptography, and number theory. Algebraic topology on the other hand developed more recently, in the 19th century, and aims to study a general notion of shape, less rigid than the idea of shape studied in geometry. It has found striking applications in the last decade, for instance to robotics and to the analysis of large data sets, and a recent revolution in the foundations of algebraic topology has broadened its applicability to other fields of pure mathematics. The proposal of the PI will bring the considerable machinery and insight of algebraic topology to bear on several well-known questions and conjectures in algebraic geometry. Some of these questions will be investigated jointly with students as part of undergraduate research projects in the Mathematical Computing Laboratory at UIC, which the PI founded in 2015 with David Dumas and Jan Verschelde. This integration will provide valuable opportunities for students to engage in research and impact ongoing research.

The PI will work on several projects at the border of algebraic geometry and algebraic topology. Three projects aim to use various topological methods to understand the Brauer group and Azumaya algebras as well as the role of higher algebraic structures in algebraic geometry. (1) The PI will study (higher) algebraic representatives of étale cohomology classes, generalizing the connection between the Picard and Brauer groups and low-degree cohomology groups. (2) The PI will explore separate applications of motivic homotopy theory and persistent homology to the period-index conjecture with the aim of finding algebraic counterexamples to the conjecture. (3) The PI will explore the Hochschild-Kostant-Rosenberg theorem in characteristic p, specifically focusing on the question of whether or not the local-global spectral sequence for Hochschild homology degenerates at the E_2-page for smooth projective surfaces in characteristic 2.

por.por_cntn:
The CAREER grant supported the PI's research into fundamental questions related to the disciplines of mathematics called algebraic topology, algebraic geometry, and number theory.

Algebraic topology is the youngest of these areas and is concerned with the study of large-scale phenomena of spaces using algebraic structures built up out of matrices and polynomials. Algebraic geometry is the study of the geometry of solution spaces of polynomial equations. Finally, number theory is about, among other things, the solutions of polynomial equations not with decimal coefficients, but with integer or rational number coefficients.

These fields are all gigantic, active areas of collective endeavor which, in addition to being studied for their own sake, are applied in all areas of science, such as engineering, computer science, physics, and chemistry.

By far the most important result during this period is the PI's discovery, with Achim Krause and Thomas Nikolaus of the University of Munster in Germany, of an efficient algorithm to compute so-called K-groups of the rings of interest in modular arithmetic, called the "integers modulo m". These K-groups are mysterious and notoriously difficult to compute. While known to be effectively computable before, previous algorithms were impractical even in very low degrees.

The development of this algorithm combines one of the main threads of research in the CAREER grant, namely a specific locus of interaction between all three fields above in application to trace methods. This is made possible by recent breakthrough work of Bhargav Bhatt, Matthew Morrow, and Peter Scholze on prismatic cohomology and its relationship to K-groups. The PI's work gives the first computational approach to prismatic cohomology and is set to open up an entire new area of research in algorithms in algebraic geometry and number theory.

In total, the PI's work during the grant produced 19 papers and preprints addressing several problems in the grant proposal and it laid the groundwork for major progress on other lingering issues. Several of those papers appeared in the top journals of mathematics. The intellectual merit of that work lies in its resolution of long-standing problems and the creation of new lines of inquiry. 

The broader impacts of the work during the grant program include the creation of a fundamental new bridge between important topics in the pure mathematical fields listed above and practical algorithmic matters in computer algebra and computer science. For example, in Fall 2022, the PI ran a one-quarter workshop for 15 students, mostly graduate students, in the math department at Northwestern focused on implementing foundational computer algebra algorithms.

Another broader impact is the creation of opportunities for deep learning by graduate students of emerging hot topics. The grant supported the first ``Vitamin K'' workshop in the summer of 2018. This workshop was a rapid, intensive reading of a breakthrough paper in K-theory by a group of 30-40 early-career mathematicians. It also supported a major, international summer school on "trace methods" in K-theory, bringing many of the world's experts to the United States to expose students here to these ideas for the first time.
